newsitem.title: USA: Rockwell to ramp up K56 chip production.
newsitem.headline: Rockwell to ramp up K56 chip production.

text.p: Rockwell International Corp said Monday it plans to make more than a million of its new K56 modem chips sets monthly in the second calender quarter of this year with shipments of a million or more by June.
"We expect to ramp up very quickly the volume production of our chipsets," Dwight Decker, president of Rockwell Semiconductors Systems said in a teleconference.

"By June we would be shipping, under our expectations, in excess of a million units a month and then it will continue to grow from there ... It will certainly grow to more than a million units a month," he added.
The new K56 modem chip sets will allow consumers to connect to the Internet over conventional telephone lines at almost twice the rate of currently available speeds.
Decker said the company expects modems using the K56 chip will be available in retail stores sometime in March adding that he expects them to be priced at about $200 each.
"By June I would expect there be between two, three, four million units already deployed in the field," he said.

The new Rockwell technology will compete with the "x2" modems being launched by U.S. Robotics Corp. The two technologies are not compatible which may mean on-line service providers may have to offer separate access numbers for end-users.

"It may be confusing for some of these end users and that's unfortunate," Decker said. "Some of the individual network providers may need to support both technologies to get their subscribers the service that they want ... it's more confusing that I think everybody would like to see."
